name: British Irish Chamber of Commerce
goal: The British Irish Chamber of Commerce was founded in 2011 ahead of the historic visit of HM Queen Elizabeth II to Ireland and the subsequent State visit of President Michael D. Higgins to Britain. The objective of the Chamber is to champion the â‚¬66 billion annual trade between the UK and Ireland which directly sustains over 400,000 jobs. We are a bilateral Chamber, engaging members from across two islands and five legislative bodies in meaningful dialogue with a common purpose.
interests: Agriculture, Banking and financial services, Budget, Business and Industry, Climate Action, Communication, Competition, Consumers, Culture, Customs, Digital economy and society, Economy, finance and the euro, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, Energy, Enlargement, Environment, External Relations, Food Safety, General and Institutional Affairs, International co-operation and development, Justice and Fundamental Rights, Maritime affairs and fisheries, Public Health, Research and innovation, Single market, Sport, Taxation, Trade, Transport
euInitiatives: The British Irish Chamber of Commerce is primarily interested in maximising the trade between the UK and Ireland. Consequently we are particularly interested in the UK's exit from the European Union and how this will impact on Irish to UK trade.
